category_summary_html:
The day's discussions centered on calibrating expectations for AI's near-term future. Greg Brockman (OpenAI) made waves with his 2026 predictions: enterprise agent adoption and scientific acceleration will dominate.

  • Rodney Brooks released his annual predictions scorecard, offering sobering contrarian views‚Äîrobotic dexterity will remain "pathetic" vs. human hands through 2036, and only Waymo and Zoox matter for US self-driving
  • Neel Nanda (Anthropic) spotlighted new MATS research on the "science of misalignment," investigating sketchy AI behaviors empirically
  • Ethan Mollick shared conceptual frameworks (Promethean Gap, Jevons Paradox, Goodhart's Law) for navigating AI's societal implications and argued AI skeptics should engage rather than opt out
  • Boris Cherny (Anthropic) provided practical Claude Code guidance; Nathan Lambert (AI2/HuggingFace) offered technical insights on MoE training instabilities driving new RL methods

items.title: Every so often @G_S_Bhogal puts together a list of interesting ideas. His latest: https://t.co/nUtB4...
items.content:
Every so often @G_S_Bhogal puts together a list of interesting ideas. His latest: https://t.co/nUtB4SPJUE

For 2026, I asked Gemini 3 Pro to do the same. Here is Gemini‚Äôs verbatim: 

1. The Promethean Gap
We are currently living in what philosopher G√ºnther Anders called the Promethean Gap: the widening disparity between our capacity to create technology and our capacity to imagine its consequences. In 2026, as AI agents begin to act autonomously, we will produce effects we cannot emotionally or morally comprehend. The tool has outpaced the user‚Äôs conscience.

2. Jevons Paradox
As AI makes intelligence and content creation cheaper and more efficient, we will not use less of it; we will use exponentially more. Expect an explosion of demand for compute and energy, not a reduction. Efficiency does not lead to conservation; it leads to consumption.

3. Audience Capture
The digital trap where creators are slowly reshaped by the feedback loops of their followers. To maintain engagement, they become caricatures of themselves, adopting extreme views they don't actually hold because that is what the algorithm (and the audience) rewards. In 2026, entire political movements are victims of audience capture.

4. Epistemic Trespassing
A growing annoyance where experts in one field (like computer science) confidently assert authority in another (like biology or geopolitics) without realizing their competence doesn't transfer. As polymaths vanish, trespassers rise.

5. Hyperstition
A portmanteau of "hype" and "superstition." It is a fiction that makes itself true. The classic example is a run on a bank; the modern example is a meme coin or a political narrative. If enough people believe a fake scenario is real, they act in ways that bring it about. We are now manufacturing our own reality.

6. The Shirky Principle
"Institutions will try to preserve the problem to which they are the solution." As AI threatens to solve complex problems (like translation or basic legal work), watch old institutions fight to keep the problems alive to justify their existence.

7. Gall‚Äôs Law
"A complex system that works is invariably found to have evolved from a simple system that worked." You cannot build a complex AI-integrated society from scratch. It must grow from functioning, simple roots. Attempts to engineer a perfect complex system instantly (like a new smart city or government) always fail.

8. The Tocqueville Paradox
As living standards improve, people‚Äôs tolerance for remaining dissatisfactions decreases. The better things get, the angrier we feel about what is still wrong. This explains why 2026 might feel like a time of crisis despite objective metrics of abundance.

9. Constructal Law
A physics principle stating that for a flow system (like a river, a tree, or society) to persist, it must evolve to provide easier access to the currents that flow through it. Society is reorganizing itself not for fairness or happiness, but to maximize the flow of information and energy.

10. Ergodicity
The difference between the group average and the individual experience. If 100 people play Russian Roulette, the "group average" survival rate is 98.3%. But if one person plays it 100 times, the survival rate is 0%. Do not confuse the safety of the collective with your safety as an individual.

11. Legibility
A concept from James C. Scott. States and algorithms want to make complex, messy human lives "legible"‚Äîeasy to measure, tax, and categorize. But in the process of tidying up the mess (standardizing education, farming, or speech), they often destroy the hidden ecosystem that made it work in the first place.

12. The Semmelweis Reflex
The knee-jerk tendency to reject new evidence because it contradicts established norms. Named after Ignaz Semmelweis, who was ridiculed for suggesting doctors wash their hands. In 2026, the "crazy" ideas about health or tech that experts mock may be the ones that save you.

items.title:
13. Mimetic Desire
You don‚Äôt want things because you want them; you want them because other people w...
items.content:
13. Mimetic Desire
You don‚Äôt want things because you want them; you want them because other people want them. Social media is a machine for accelerating mimetic desire, creating bubbles of envy for things (like specific careers or lifestyles) that have no intrinsic value to you.

14. Brandolini‚Äôs Law
Also known as the Bullshit Asymmetry Principle: The amount of energy needed to refute bullshit is an order of magnitude larger than is needed to produce it. With generative AI, the cost of producing bullshit has dropped to zero. We are drowning in asymmetry.

15. The Cobra Effect
When an attempted solution makes the problem worse due to perverse incentives. (The British offered a bounty for dead cobras in Delhi; people started breeding cobras to collect the bounty). Watch for policies in 2026 that incentivize the exact behavior they try to ban (like "hate speech" laws creating more trolls).

16. Chesterton‚Äôs Fence
Do not remove a fence until you know why it was put there. As we rush to "disrupt" industries and traditions with AI, we are tearing down fences (social norms, institutions) without understanding the protection they provided against chaos.

17. The Lindy Effect
The future life expectancy of a non-perishable thing (like a book or an idea) is proportional to its current age. The Bible will outlast the latest self-help bestseller. To survive 2026, bet on things that have already survived 2,000 years, not 2 years.

18. Predictive Processing
Your brain does not see the world; it hallucinates a prediction of the world and corrects it only when there is an error. We are trapped in our own controlled hallucinations. Understanding this helps you realize that your "reality" is just a best-guess simulation.

19. Egregores
An occult term for a "collective group mind." When a corporation, a subreddit, or a political party takes on a life of its own, acting in ways no single member intended, it has become an Egregore. You are not fighting people; you are fighting autonomous psychic entities.

20. Sayre‚Äôs Law
"In any dispute, the intensity of feeling is inversely proportional to the value of the issues at stake." This is why Twitter (X) arguments are so vicious‚Äîbecause the stakes are so low.

21. Hormesis
The biological phenomenon where a beneficial effect results from a low dose of an agent that is otherwise toxic. Stress, cold, and hunger (in small doses) make you stronger. Comfort is a slow poison; managed volatility is the cure.

22. Goodhart‚Äôs Law
"When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure." If you measure AI by how human it sounds, it will learn to lie like a human. If you measure success by likes, you get clickbait. All metrics in 2026 are compromised.

23. The Moloch Trap
A game-theoretic situation where individual incentives force everyone to sacrifice value, even though everyone would be better off if they coordinated. (e.g., beauty filters: everyone uses them to compete, so nobody looks better relative to others, but everyone feels uglier). We are sacrificing our humanity to Moloch.

24. Shifting Baseline Syndrome
Each generation accepts the state of the world they were born into as "normal." We don't realize how much silence, nature, or privacy we've lost because our baseline keeps resetting downward.

25. Paradox of Tolerance
If a society is tolerant without limit, its ability to be tolerant is eventually seized or destroyed by the intolerant. To maintain a tolerant society, the society must be intolerant of intolerance. The battle of 2026 will be defining who "the intolerant" are.

26. Wu Wei
The Taoist concept of "inexertion" or "effortless action." In a world of infinite AI noise and "grindset" hustle, the most effective action is often to do nothing‚Äîto wait, watch, and let the mud settle until the water is clear. Force creates resistance; flow creates victory.

items.title:
The biggest barrier isn't technology. It is legacy complexity.

Take aviation as an example.

A majo...
items.content:
The biggest barrier isn't technology. It is legacy complexity.

Take aviation as an example.

A major airline operates over 1,000 aircraft supported by 80 separate homegrown apps.

IFS CEO Mark Moffat warns that AI can't fix that complexity alone.

You have to use simulation at scale to pressure-test workflows millions of times before they touch a real turbine.
items.author: @Ronald_vanLoon
items.summary: Discussion of legacy complexity as main barrier to AI adoption, using airline example with 1000+ aircraft and 80 homegrown apps requiring simulation testing.
items.reasoning: Insightful observation about real enterprise AI challenges. Practical perspective on why AI transformation is difficult. Good aviation example.

items.title:
Look back, 2025 is the year when I really felt the AGI (instead of just rationally expecting it).

C...
items.content:
Look back, 2025 is the year when I really felt the AGI (instead of just rationally expecting it).

Coming from self-driving, I probably had a much longer timeline than the average Silicon Valley tech bro. 

Because I‚Äôve seen the long tail, the irreducible complexity of the physical world that ML struggled to generalize to.

But coding agents of 2025 (esp. Claude and family) did surprise me. The slope is just much steeper.

Looks like code writing & execution will be the primary substrate, not just for SWE, but most aspects of general automation. 

It‚Äôs the planning, memory, and integration layer for most long horizon, complex tasks. We don‚Äôt need more abstractions. 

Excited for 2026.
items.author: @disiok
items.summary: AI practitioner from self-driving background reflects on 2025 as the year they 'felt' AGI - coding agents surprised them, code execution may be the primary substrate for general automation
items.reasoning: Thoughtful perspective from someone with self-driving ML background, provides interesting comparison. Low engagement but original insight.

Happy New Year, and stay tuned!

I used to think automation meant shaving minutes off reconciliations or approvals.

What I saw here is different.

A few examples of what an AI native core can handle instantly:

‚Üí Documents that become transactions through OCR
‚Üí Bank lines that auto match
‚Üí Anomalies flagged before approvals
‚Üí Reports built automatically based on rules you define once

This is not workflow automation, it is autonomous accounting.

items.title: Thanks to sheer natural resources and WWII, America became the strongest economy in the '70s because...
items.content:
Thanks to sheer natural resources and WWII, America became the strongest economy in the '70s because 1) they invented and created the most advanced tech, 2) they only shared the tech with their allies (Japan, S. Korea, Israel).

Then came traitors and liberals. Traitors began giving the cutting-edge tech to China for cheaper reproduction. Liberals started publishing the cutting-edge research for vanity.

The Chinese, being poor but well-educated and more hardworking, first learned to copy. Then they learned to do better.

It took them only 40 years‚Äînothing compared to the age of Chinese civilization.

Compared to the age of Chinese civilization, America lost its unbreakable domination in the blink of an eye, thanks to traitors and liberals.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov makes political argument about US tech decline due to 'traitors and liberals' sharing tech with China
items.reasoning: Off-topic political commentary, not substantive AI analysis.
